reviews.text: I can only take so much messiah talk in science fiction, especially when it’s coming from Javier Bardem and Timothée Chalamet, both of whom I generally like, but here all I could think about was that they’d played Desi Arnaz and Bob Dylan.
The massive cast, who could have easily felt like a Shakespeare-on-the-Beach ensemble, have fully bought in and are working overtime to ensure we do too.

I found reasons to avoid it all year long. Finally catching it on the small screen, I was enthralled, mostly thanks to Zendaya distracting from the tiresome Atreides white messiah complex, but also because it finally embraced BIG sci-fi battles
I'm constantly in awe of Villeneuve, and this chapter was the movie we were all waiting for.
A very good film, but one that falls short of that elusive classic status.
Right from sound, camera work, and VFX to sharp and crisp editing, Dune 2 aces in every technical department.
Denis Villeneuve's sequel is a beautiful crash bang wallop of a film that is overpowering in its splendour and scale - a sci-fi film for people who don’t like sci-fi.
Bigger, bolder and more satisfying, Dune: Part Two triumphs over its predecessor.
Pt. 2 is massive, mind-blowing, less complex with much better pacing, better character development and expands the DuneMovie verse with culminating powers.
It almost feels like a miracle that Denis Villeneuve got to make a Dune adaptation this bold and daring in the current studio system.
Dune: Part Two is a masterpiece that surpasses the high expectations set by Part One, a movie so good, it will make you forget the horror of its popcorn bucket.
A monstrous achievement for the Sci-Fi genre, Denis Villeneuve’s Dune Part Two is all guts and glory with an end result that feels like sanctified storytelling.
I need a buddy comedy between Stilgar and Josh Brolin's Gurney Halleck.
Just as The Empire Strikes Back was an improvement upon A New Hope, this too is an improvement upon its predecessor. It’s a perfect sci-fi epic.
For all its talk about centuries-old religious sects, intergalactic trading guilds, and foretold messiahs, Dune: Part Two is a movie about power and the material resources used to secure it.

Denis Villeneuve’s much-awaited sequel to 2021’s spi-fi epic, Dune, is the first truly great film of 2024. Dune: Part Two’s scope is awe-inspiring, its pacing is electric, and the themes it explores are suspenseful and thought-provoking.

Dune: Part Two leads you on with the idea that we’re watching an avenging hero. In reality, we’re seeing the inevitable, deeply disconcerting outcome of where following a messiah figure takes a culture.
I would be remiss to not mention Rebecca Ferguson owning the screen as Lady Jessica. This film and cast is too stacked to give it fully adequate treatment in a mere blurb...

“Two: A Spice Odyssey”: Villeneuve’s gorgeous, brute parable of generational rage, interplanetary revenge and exploitation of masses for the production of magical fuel that extends dynastic rule... is freed from the garrulous exposition of the first.
(Timothée Chalamet) is blessed with a remarkable head of hair that defies the desert’s dryness. There’s not an ounce of frizz on those wavy tresses.

Villeneuve continues to push boundaries by creating thematically rich epics. We take these movies for granted, but when filmmakers are asked to take fewer risks, I am grateful for weird, grim blockbusters like Dune: Part Two.
Villeneuve sets a new standard for big-budget, premium-format-ready filmmaking, delivering an aesthetic masterwork that shames its peers.
When viewed as one long film with an intermission, Dune is a spectacular achievement. The problem is the intermission took three years.

The weight of this world is presented as a matter-of-fact reality, and this solemn approach adds weight to the drama even when individual elements do not coalesce. We take the events here with operatic seriousness, all the way to their bitter end.
Denis Villeneuve's long-awaited sequel, Dune: Part Two, effectively delivers the full force of Frank Herbert's epic saga and is set to be a modern classic.

Dune Part 2 is bolder and much more bombastic than the first instalment. In terms of cinematography and direction, this film is comparable to the sweeping epics of David Lean’s Lawrence of Arabia, Star Wars and Blade Runner.
Dune is a story that combines science fiction, religion, ecology, amazing production value, and a dozen well-known actors. [Full review in Spanish]
The key issues of Dune remain the key issues of Dune, but Denis Villeneuve has created a visual language for Dune that finally gives this epic its cinematic due.
A triumph of style over substance.

That lull of a bridge episode pushing us forward with action scenes and betrayal so that the lines can be drawn in the sand for future drama (this is pretty much an over-long epilogue leading towards MESSIAH).
Denis Villeneuve finds the humanity at the core of this sprawling sci-fi epic.

If Part One was more interesting in terms of plotting and character development, Part Two scores slightly higher in political intrigue and sheer spectacle, even if the dictates of the storyline sometimes make it feel more familiar (Lawrence of Arrakis?).
If Villeneuve makes good on his recent talk of making a third movie (based on Herbert’s sequel, “Dune Messiah”), “Dune: Part Two” is the downpayment that tells us it’s going to be spectacular.
Dune: Part Two is a generational film; the rare release that reaffirms why I believe in cinema.

Dune: Part Two features the same technical brilliance as the first film, as well as a remarkably talented cast, but it also suffers from the same problems as before thanks to a weak screenplay with poor story & character development and sluggish pacing.
It’s a credit to Villeneuve and his team that these films are as impossibly good as they can be, even when aspects are unevenly approached in order to play with so many characters in the story.
There's some incredible world building and cinematography here but I didn't feel emotionally connected to any of the characters.
It is a visual marvel that is unevenly paced and emotionally distant. Solid sci-fi film but was left with an empty feeling that didn't excite me for what may come next.
So alien in appearance, so human in its themes, Dune: Part Two is a peerless sci-fi film for the ages.
I drank a Red Bull before seeing Dune: Part 2. ... I should have had two. Maybe then it would have been easier to get through this at times ponderous and repetitive sci-fi sequel.
...a ponderous and terminally underwhelming (and uninvolving) endeavor that strikes all the wrong notes right from the get-go...
Villeneuve delivers a certain solemnity through the visual and sounding side, but the land swallows his narrative and spits out the residues in the sand. [Full review in Spanish]

Villeneuve gives us much more to appreciate in his second Dune missive: Rousing action sequences ranging from worm-riding to tense knife fights and large-scale battles, and a thorough seat-soaker of a finale which combines all of the above.
From self-parody to epic, "Dune, part two", by Denis Villeneuve, contains several possible versions of itself, but none truly great. [Full review in Spanish]
We get so many movies that use up the space Dune: Part Two does, but a very, very few manage to do so much with a canvas like this. Much like the great sequels before it, this film is essential.
Villeneuve brings the epic scope, Zendaya brings the heart and humanity.

When all is said and done, this can only be described as an unapologetic rave.... Director Denis Villeneuve jumps into what could easily be a by-the-books franchise sequel and creates a cinematic feast for the senses.
Dune: Part Two is a must-watch epic sci-fi, visually stunning, adventure that could already be considered the best movie of the year.

As a sequel, it works for the same reasons that make The Empire Strikes Back so many people’s favourite Star Wars film: there’s a darkness, a bleakness, that makes the fist-pumping moments feel all-the-more earned.

...rich in multilayered world-building. While its dense story might leave some cold, this is a movie meant for big-screen grandeur, from the detailed costumes to the cinematography, special effects, and score.

For much of its 167-minute runtime, the action builds itself up slowly but surely, teasingly incremental in its climb – but in its final act, Paul’s story hurtles its way towards a thunderous, earth-shattering climax.
A must watch! [Full review in Spanish]
The film is exquisitely beautiful and immersive, breathtaking in scope, and fearless in delivering stunning action sequences that are so vivid they practically erupt from the screen.

Dune Part Two is bigger in almost every way. The visual effects, sound design, and production as a whole is immaculate. Narratively, it does feel a bit too unresolved by the end for my taste but hopefully Dune: Messiah comes sooner rather than later.
Visually stunning yet sterile - with an emphasis on action, as opposed to exposition and character-development, resulting in a shallow, self-important sequel.

If you are watching “Dune: Part Two” with the right mindset, i.e. from Chani’s point of view, you should be watching the film with growing dread and concerned about Paul, not cheering how everything is coming together.
As different from the first film as [Ridley Scott's] Alien is to [James Cameron's] Aliens. Same stuff, totally different genre!
"Dune is a stunning, sweeping epic with a cast in command of their roles [...] Part Two really cements Dune as one of our greatest modern examples of epic genre worldbuilding."
Holding her own amidst a powerful team, Zendaya exudes her own defiant looks in a harsh world where both people and nature challenge survival.

With an engaging story, a cast at their very best, along with stunning visuals, this is a masterpiece---as with the Oscar-winning first installment, Villeneuve shows visual mastery of, impressive cinematography, while maintaining an emotional heartbeat.
Dune: Part Two improves upon its predecessor, thanks to a bigger focus on the Fremen, but its inclusiveness is still watered down.
“Dune: Part Two” is the type of film that will engross you with its beauty and complexity yet might confuse you at the same time. It is an epic tale worthy of the big-screen experience.

"DUNE: PART TWO improves on its predecessor in some crucial ways, but the reliance on spectacle leaves gaps in the storytelling and a frustratingly ephemeral interest in the most interesting ideas the film brings forward."

Directed with ferocity by Denis Villeneuve, the film pushes the envelope with its gripping dark atmosphere, suspenseful hunts and ambushes, intricate rituals and prophecies, psychedelic imagery, and exhilarating fights set against magnificent backdrops.
There is little character development and it’s not for the literal-minded -- or anyone who has, despite their best efforts, paid some attention.

Denis Villeneuve is the director of this massive undertaking... Also, on board here is composer Hans Zimmer with his unforgettable background music and Greig Fraser as the cinematographer who gets those gigantic sand worms into action.
Dune: Part Two is a movie that feels like the culmination of everything that can make a big epic story like this great on the big screen.
Tonally inconsistent, this second chapter rarely feels like a Villeneuve film.
Collides dense sci-fi imagemaking with Herbert’s heady and prescient themes: the gravity of manufactured destiny, the untamable tendrils of belief, and a harrowing subversion of the hero’s journey.

I found the film to be long and dragged out, while the cultural and religious aspects felt whitewashed. The film is star-studded with actors like Christopher Walken that felt more like glorified cameos that don’t add much to the story.
On every level, it's a set of cinematic genius. The craft is expertly made, and it shows in every shot, every note of the [score], and every scene that transports the audience to Arrakis.
This was the best adaptation of a book that I've ever seen.

The film warns us against the very thing it gives us. We watch from reclining chairs as Paul starts a holy war—our hands are clean. We get the heroic battles and the guilt on the side. Our hero is tortured so we don’t have to be.

An incredible sci-fi epic that well surpasses the first part and achieves on every level. This might be the best sci-fi film we've had in many years and will likely be one of the best films of the year.
Dune feels without tears. Dune speaks without words.
Toppled by arid self-importance.
Epic visually, but the story is still hard to follow if you have not read the book.
Dune: Part Two is a singular vision painted on an enormous cinematic canvas. See it on the biggest screen you can.

With his second foray into Frank Herbert's universe, Denis Villeneuve has once again crafted a cinematic juggernaut designed to be seen on the biggest screen and heard through the most powerful sound system possible.

Denis Villeneuve uses Dune: Part Two (2024), cowritten with Jon Spaihts, to examine the experience of being set before the prophecy, knowing you’re its intended subject. [... T]his narrative structure is famously hinted at in the Gospels.

The genius of the author, Herbert, and now the director, Villeneuve, is to weave all this complexity into an easily understood, and compelling story. It's been tried before, but this is the first time it has really worked.

Ugly, outrageous, brutal, and cynical; a genuinely terrifying film about power and politics as religion and control. There is little escapism here; hits square in the social plexus of horrifying 2024.
Like George Lucas and Ridley Scott, filmmaker Denis Villeneuve proves himself a visionary by delivering one of the greatest science fiction films of all time.

Where it really comes into its own as a hugely satisfying Hollywood sci-fi epic is in the action-adventure material, which is also backloaded, so the very long film seems to keep getting bigger and richer as it goes along.

[Dune 2] owes its intellectual interest to Herbert’s books. Is faith merely another resource to be exploited in the quest for power? ... Or is it real, tapping into a true well of knowledge and sustenance? The Dune series asks but doesn’t try to answer.
Grains of sand, not pixels, give Denis Villeneuve's spectacle its potent spice, in this urgent and compelling conclusion.
Like its predecessor, Dune Part Two is gorgeously filmed and prodigiously imagined.
The film's real center of gravity is its spectacle, the craft with which Villeneuve and his crew depict Herbert's stupendously complex worlds.
It's impressive filmmaking.
An epic and spectacular sci-fi allegory with mass appeal.

Whether you think you're interested in a sci-fi or not, this is a powerful and quite beautiful reminder of what a stunning medium cinema can still be, when enough ambition, intelligence, artistry – and money – all come together in the same place. Bravo.
You know Villeneuve will get the spectacle right. The question is about the human drama… It almost all connected in Part Two.

I did not watch Dune: Part Two, I experienced it. From the beautiful majesty of its visuals to the awe-inspiring sound design and the fantastic production design, this film was an absolute joy to behold.
The rest of us get to be Zendaya’s Chani — charmed but not won over, and both expecting as well as deserving more than what she gets...
As with the Oscar-winning first instalment, Villeneuve shows mastery of scale and scope, with stunning cinematography and a thumping score from Hans Zimmer.
This is easily Zendaya's best on-screen performance to date, and her future in the series will no doubt expand into further joy.

The picture doesn´t ignore the Orientalism described by Edward Said in its own approach and how this influences the viewer's perception of the characters no matter how much the film tries to avoid those pitfalls. [Full review in Portuguese]
Epic sci-fi film.

Dune: Part Two is the real deal in terms of sci-fi epics, and will probably end up being one of the most defining films of the genre for the next decade to come. It’s a tremendous work and stunning sequel that is simply unparalleled.

It’s curious to say that a two-hour, 45-minute epic of this tonnage is holding something back, but Villeneuve is (once again) just as interested in prophesying the next film as he is in cementing the current one.

As in all of these sci-fi epics, there are plenty of scenes in which computer-generated characters drive computer-generated vehicles past computer-generated backdrops but, in "Dune," it feels human, slightly messy and organic.

DUNE: PART TWO is an exceptional cinematic achievement in storytelling from Denis Villeneuve with a completely memorable score from Hans Zimmer and electric performances from Timothee Chalamet, Zendaya, Rebecca Ferguson and Austin Butler.

Cultural appropriation aside, there are too many characters to do them justice in a film more focused on the grandiose than the granular motivations of its side players or a more fervent exploration of imperialism and colonialism beyond "good vs bad."

It feels more confident [as] he’s benefiting from the fact that he’s done the hard work. He’s set up the lore and the backstory in the first movie. The exposition of like “Oh, look at how this spaceship works. [...] This is why Arrakis is important.”
What is really impressive about Part Two, is that despite how complex and like a miasma the plot becomes... the storytelling is so clear.
I still don’t love the material or the movies-but I recommend the sequel based on its kinetic first act, overall cast potency, thrilling sound, and overall satisfying qualities.

Impeccably shot, superb visual effects, and dripping with mostly strong performances from its entire cast, Villnueve’s latest will have you almost entirely invested in the dry, twisty, and monochromatic sci-fi drama for nearly all of its three hours.

Villeneuve conjures memories of “Lawrence of Arabia” more than once and gets some gorgeous visuals just holding on untouched sand dunes. When he introduces those worms, the action heats up and Chalamet gets to ride to glory.

Is Villeneuve's Dune a flawless adaptation? Not at all, nor is it a film free of blemishes. But it is one that solves its difficulties with finesse, and that stands out when it refuses to give in to the easy epic. [Full review in Spanish]
Dune: Part Two is undeniably spectacular. Whether and how much one is moved by that spectacle depends on large part on what else, if anything, the viewer wants from it.
With an unforgettable score, vivid visuals, and powerful performances, Dune: Part Two is what a sci-fi epic should be.
In Dune: Part Two, Villeneuve is less subtle with his choices, being aggressively vocal about the film’s intent, leaving very little room for ambiguity.
Dune: Part Two works as an epic conclusion to the introduction in the first Dune. Part Two works better as the conclusion, experiencing as one cohesive story rather than two parts of one whole.
The first "Dune" was fun; the follow-up no longer has the element of surprise and falls flat as a desert mouse getting steamrollered by a giant sand worm.

Finally, DUNE takes proper cinematic shape as the glorious sci-fi soap opera metaphor intended by Frank Herbert in Villeneuve's continuation, although its most potent offerings exist in the periphery.

In terms of settling the various pending accounts of the first part, as well as introducing and resolving the second part, the film performs satisfactorily despite the occasional anticlimax... [Full review in Spanish]

I'll be telling my kids about the day I went to the theatre and watched the "Dune" saga. A celebration of human imagination, from its serious reflections to its wildest ideas. A cinematographic feat. [Full review in Spanish]

It builds on what worked in the first film, and firmly establishes that it has been constructed out of not only an affection for the source material, but also a profound understanding of the tragedy at the heart of Herbert’s work.
In a genre once jokingly called space opera, its grand aristocratic dynasties and passions justify the term.

This movie displays all manner of magnificence — black suns and 800mph winds, sandstorm assassins and massive stone ziggurats, all in a palette of grey and beige like a Mesopotamian temple renovated by Jasper Conran.

The result is a staggering statement of near biblical approach — a risk-taking endeavor to storytelling that threatens to derail at any minute, but is kept whole by Villeneuve’s smartly conceived narrative.
Exceeds expectations in every way—except humanity.
Dune 2 ignites the essence missing from its predecessor. With a pulsating heartbeat, it weaves characters and world-building into a sci-fi odyssey akin to a biblical epic.

The recently released sequel "Dune: Part Two" is a large-scale visual and narrative contribution to the science fiction genre. Much more, it is a sophisticated twist on the Messiah cliché. All in a breathtakingly majestic setting. [Full Review in Spanish

A major blockbuster that tells us a lot about colonisation, cultural appropriation, religious fervour, and the way we perceive our leaders. I liked “Dune: Part 2” even more than its predecessor. Full review in Spanish.

When the film centers on real locations and real structures and props Greig Fraser’s cinematography and Villeneuve’s vision come through clearly. Unfortunately, the film is heavily reliant on visual effects that often look poor at best.
There is so much to admire and praise here, Dune: Part Two is too big to ignore and a major cinematic event.
Dune: Part Two is a breathtaking trip to another world, a fever dream from which we never want to wake.
The film is all exhilarating buildup leading to an unsatisfactory, and even somewhat perfunctory, payoff.
This is what movie theaters exist for, this type of visual and complete story immersion.
Character, you may think, is not the point of a story like this one – it’s myth-making, allegory – but without real people to care about, there’s a ceiling on how invested we can become.

This second part disregards most of the story’s nuances in favour of stunning action sequences that engulf the screen with battles and explosions, and feature the mightiness of the monstrous worms that inhabit the planet.

The second Dune instalment is jaw-on-the-floor spectacular. It elegantly weaves together top-tier special effects and arresting cinematography; it layers muscle, sinew and savagery on to the bones of Part One.
Overwhelming visuals and a pummeling score work hard to give this a constant bone-deep sense of profundity and meaning, even where the story itself is just a series of rebel attacks on farm trucks
Dune: Part Two is why we go to the movies. Read up on the legend beforehand, especially if you haven’t seen Part One, settle in with some popcorn and marvel at what masterful filmmaking is all about.
Dune: Part Two not only lives up to its anticipation but also sets a high bar for epic storytelling, leaving audiences craving more.
Bouncing between something great and something terrible, Dune: Part Two lands firmly in the middle as a good yet ultimately flawed action epic.
The special effects are spectacular; the costumes are arresting. Makeup and sets are out of this world. All the actors did a fine job, and I loved the dynamic between Chani and Paul.

Visually, this movie is incredibly stunning. I didn't like the original version, but this one is absolutely fantastic. It's easier to follow and the story is more straightforward. This is the rare case where the sequel is better than the original.

If you like intergalactic shootings, you'll have it; But if you want more and get involved in metaphysics, apocalyptic ecology, religion, mass manipulation, fanaticism and love; You'll also find something to discuss for hours. [Full Review in Spanish]

Lawrence of Arrakis meets Dr. Sandworm, or, How I Learned to Stop Worrying and Love the Bene Gesserit...The result is a blockbuster space opera that plays like a downbeat drama — we’re a long, long way from that famous galaxy far, far away.

I'm the biggest sucker on this planet for space opera shenanigans and proud giver-of-an-A-grade to Jupiter Ascending. With this budget and Villeneuve’s visuals, the worst this could be is a mostly good time. 

Dune 2: The Dunening is a mostly good time.

The gifted Quebecois filmmaker unleashes all his big guns, including a couple of eyeworthy sandworm-riding experiences that might rock your soul while shaking the large-screen viewing venue at which you likely will be enjoying first-class cinema.
The magnitude of the story and the level of artistry here is that rare occasion where you become so emersed in what you are watching you forget where you are when the credit roll.
Dune: Part Two was well worth the wait and exceeds all expectations.
Dune: Part Two should be seen on the biggest screen you can find, but the story remains a riveting saga both classical and imaginative.

Crucial to Villeneuve's take on Dune, and to his work in general, is seeing and feeling the minutiae; Paul's path and inner conflict, and Chani's reaction to it in particular, wouldn't cut as deeply otherwise.
With Dune: Part Two, the Canadian [Villeneuve] no longer has to prove anything. [Full review in Spanish]

As a feat of project management, Dune: Part Two is undeniable. But given how fundamentally bizarre the world of Dune is—or should be—critical consensus seems like an odd goal. Shouldn't it be weirder?
For a big Hollywood blockbuster, Dune is unafraid to say some very dark things about religion, politics, power and violence.
One of the year’s most anticipated films is nice to look at, but is let down by bland acting and a script that does no great service to its impressive cast.
A vast improvement on the first part with a complete story and epic scope.

Even as we marvel at the stunning and immersive and Oscar-level cinematography, editing, score, visual effects, production design and sound in Denis Villeneuve’s Part Two, we’re reminded at every turn that this is an absolutely crazy story...
Dune 2 is more monumental than its predecessor, and if you’re a fan waiting for this big-screen behemoth, head to a theatre pronto.

Chalamet too grows into his role as a reluctant rebel. The sequel makes room for humour. Stilgar's fervent appeals to Paul to embrace his inner messiah gives Javier Bardem some fine moments and a brooding, stately narrative a much-needed touch of levity.
Dune 2 is a visually stunning epic best consumed by those willing to invest in its world.
The effects in this movie are gorgeous.
In an age of ever-increasing runtimes, it’s a rare achievement that the film’s 166-minute length feels earned.

The ending of Dune Part Two is an improvement on the abrupt denouement of the first film, but it might still leave many in the audience a tad dissatisfied. On the positive side, it points to what Villeneuve has always had in mind - a trilogy.

An impressive second half to Denis Villeneuve’s sci-fi epic progresses the dense plot instead of just laying the groundwork. It worms its way through imposing narrative obstacles with spicy directorial choices that may be commonly misinterpreted.
The second installment is significantly better. It seems pretty clear that Part One was the movie they had to make in order to do the one they really wanted to make.

The world of Dune remains intriguingly complex, full of characters whose roles shift and evolve. Credit Villeneuve with filling the screen with enough exotic flavor and bold action to keep Dune vividly alive through two helpings.
This is truly one of most magnificent cinematic achievements of all time. Filled with breathtaking images, stunning action and a story that transcends the science fiction genre.
Villeneuve has raised the bar with Dune: Part Two, which now takes its place not just as the quintessential adaptation of the beloved novel -- but one of the top level series in its genre.
And as those prestige epics of yore were enlarged yea further by the imperial symphonics of Alex North and Miklos Rozsa, so here composer Hans Zimmer pushes for big, bigger, biggest.

There are many moving parts in Dune: Part 2, but Villeneuve, who absorbed the novels of Frank Herbert as a teenager and has been ruminating on them ever since, proves more than equal to the task of bringing this story to the screen.
'Dune' is a spectacular, procedural exercise, but 'Dune: Part Two' burns more calories.
If Dune: Part 1 didn't make you a believer; Part 2 just might.
Dune: Part Two is a powerfully effective spectacle and a masterful showcase of Villeneuve’s ability to realize worlds that are as beautiful as they are terrifying.

Another speaker-rattling Hans Zimmer score powers ominous scenes on the planet Giedi Prime, where we meet the Baron's creepy, hairless heir Feyd-Rautha (a shaven Austin Butler). This second film is odder than the first.
The sheer craft on display along with the extraordinary storytelling results in an awe-inspiring and mature science-fiction blockbuster that immediately left me hoping for a Part Three.
"Dune: Part Two" is a masterpiece of epic science fiction filmmaking.
Dune is an epic adventure, but it’s also a morality tale with one of its main themes being the dangers of co-opting religion for political power.

“Dune: Part Two” is stunning to look at, has memorable action scenes and a bevy of great performances. It loses a few points in setting up that the audience will have to pay to see at least one more film.

Dune: Part Two is the counter balance to the recent blockbuster mediocrity. The story is dense. The characters are complex.  The world is captivating, and the production is flawless.  A must see film for sci-fi fans and cinephiles.
It was terrific, but exhausting, laboriously introducing us to the inter-planetary empire Herbert imagined, and the various dynasties grappling for power or simply survival.
Instead of a theme park, it's more of a cathedral -- solemn, sober, beautiful and forbidding. Greig Fraser's photography and Hans Zimmer's score are full of majesty.

It’s all fatuous, like Peter Jackson’s Lord of the Rings films... Nothing in Villeneuve’s Dune series is as good as Zack Snyder’s Rebel Moon, which revives mythic understanding of both mankind’s history and fate.
It’s an eye-popping, sonically stunning, highly original story with massively more action, character and plot than the 2021 Dune: Part One.
A wildly-entertaining, fully-realized spectacle that cements Villeneuve's place as a best-in-a-generation stylist but raises some questions about his understanding of story.
While this sequel isn't without stuffy, slow spots, it's far more propulsive than its predecessor, and it manages to tell an exceedingly complex story in a gloriously visual and compelling way.
Fails to remain engaging for more than a few scenes at a time, thanks to images that lack vitality. Instead of letting its most uncomfortable emotions linger, it takes a much more didactic approach.
“Dune: Part Two” allows writer/director Denis Villeneuve to examine some weighty things like religion, politics and destiny in the middle of a sweeping, epic, visually stunning film. Plus, sandworms!

[Dune 2] reaches a fever pitch of seductive strangeness and operatic drama. It’s a tragedy about the dangers of power and fanatism, a romance, and a superb action movie. Villeneuve’s audacious vision has set a new standard for the cinematic sci-fi epic.
Dune: Part Two is an undeniable triumph -- a kinetic, beautifully shot exercise in wish-fulfillment whose denouement is so brutal it makes Taken seem like a model of nonviolent conflict resolution.
The film's bounty of new characters and performers give it a heightened sense of drama that’s at once both grander and more nuanced than Part One’s.

Villeneuve... seems somehow able to toggle between horizon-wide action spectacle and patient, up-close intimacy. His Dune project is an at-times breathtaking, thrilling departure for a genre rarely able to take us to genuinely new territory.
The focus on the power and the limits of faith distinguishes the Dune films from the herd.

Denis Villeneuve did what Peter Jackson did with Frank Herbert's work with Tolkien or Francis Ford Coppola with Puzo: a perfect adaptation that enriches the original text with its images.[Full Review in Spanish]
If this studious, spectacular shot at Herbert's saga can't always reconcile its warring impulses -- to dazzle and critique in equal measure -- then it's all part of the package, if not the point.

I was a fan of first Dune in this series, although I logged similar complaints about its self-seriousness. This one is a little better; the action is just as thrilling but the characters are given more depth.

Under the guidance of director Denis Villeneuve, it becomes a cinematic experience in that it’s a technical marvel showcasing the best of film with an immersive experience that almost literally knocks the viewers' socks off.
The revenge story comes to a satisfying conclusion here, while leaving the door open for more in the saga of Paul Atreides and his journey to becoming the chosen one.
Here comes Dune: Part Two to restore your faith in big-budget, big-screen moviegoing.

Visually splendid but a jumbled storytelling mess. Timothée Chalamet seems more like a sullen boy band expat than a galactic messiah. Zendaya is given little to do but glare resentfully for the last 90 minutes.

It all looks very nice, though deserts have a wearisome colour palate, and Mr Villeneuve fairly flogged the giant worms to death in the first one. It’s all a bit up itself, though Javier Bardem provides sly Life of Brian-style humour.

The imaginative visualization of its mise-en-scene makes Dune: Part Two a dazzling spectacle on a scale that is being lost in the streaming era and that requires to be seen on the big screen. [Full review in Spanish]

Part Two is not merely an improvement but almost a different film. Villeneuve's imagination is unleashed here in a way that frequently thrills, even if the actual storytelling is sometimes dutiful; it's more Jodorowsky than Lucas.
Composer Hans Zimmer added a fire engoine to the horn section.
Villeneuve spends so much time capturing the feel of Arrakis that he sometimes forgets that the audience needs to feel something toward Paul, perhaps the weakest character among the principal cast.

Just sit back and be dazzled by the world that writer/director Denis Villeneuve has so artfully created. Wrapped in Hans Zimmer’s magical, masterful score, it’s a multi-sensory experience that surpasses the first installment.
Dune: Part Two is not only a masterful action film, but a cinematic look into the soul.
Few theatrical experiences, this year or any, will be more dazzling.
Part Two is even more mesmerizing than the first. Villeneuve's magnum opus is a visceral escapist entertainment that you could practically feel the desert heat on your skin & sand in your hair.

Dune: Part Two at times expends an excess of severity and footage, particularly between the tests in the desert and the final battle. But it is also solid, attractive, and more exciting than the first installment. [Full review in Spanish]
Production-wise, Dune: Part Two is a film that delivers stunning desert vistas alongside dreary empires of destruction, but its runtime and same-old perspectives feel like been there done that.
Who knew it was possible to be so amazed and so bored at the same time?
The performances match the breathtaking visuals, making Dune: Part Two a captivating and immersive cinematic experience.

Despite veering from the content of the novel, and forgiving the lack of menace Austin Butler created, this was a phenomenal movie filled with glorious action, magnificent visuals and special effects, and passionate and dynamic performances.

Any pointed critique might get lost here in the spectacular sunsets, sleek knife fights, opulent wardrobes and blockbuster power. ... It grinds the rough edges off the source material in favour of symmetry and spectacle.
'Dune: Part Two' gives star Timothée Chalamet richer material to play, but the film still doesn’t quite capture the heart.
This movie, more than the first part, is entirely on author Frank Herbert’s wavelength.

DUNE-heads unite, & props to dir Denis Villenueve & his team for properly delivering Frank Herbert's illuminating sci-fi story of courage and prophecy. Everything you want ... epic battle, romance and loyalty/betrayal is in this incredible film. Perfect!
Ultimately, we end up with an abundance of craft and a forest of lore wrapped around personal narratives too flimsy to sustain marching feet.

Dune: Part Two is a towering achievement of artistic vision.... The only problem is, like Part One, the only way to accomplish this was to make something that is, for all intents and purposes, not even really a movie.

The year’s first surefire blockbuster is a sequel that outdoes Denis Villeneuve’s first epic 2021 sand opera. OK, it’s a tad long and solemn,  but Chalamet and Zendaya are destiny-kissed lovers to die for, and the thundering spectacle is off the charts.
If ... Dune took too much time getting to the point, the ... sequel is, perhaps, in too much of a rush to actually consider the many points it wants to make.
'Dune: Part Two' sets foot back on Arrakis with an ambitious fire in its eye, overcoming its unsteady but understandable hubris with cinematography and production value that comes utterly alive.

Throughout Villeneuve’s career, the director has had a marked disinterest in humanity. No matter the triumph or setback, each plot development and inflection point is as dry as the sands where film takes place.

If he can pull off this planned trilogy, the “Dune” films will join “Metropolis” (1927), “2001: A Space Odyssey” (1968), and “Blade Runner” (1982) as among the most significant achievements in science fiction cinema and, indeed, in all film.
“Dune: Part Two” see’s filmmaker Denis Villeneuve stunningly best his 2021 entry at every spice-dusted turn.
I wish this film had grabbed my head and heart more. But I recommend that you see it – preferably in Imax – and let the visuals and the entrancing score by Hans Zimmer wash over you.

... believable spectacle on a nigh impossible scale... Chalamet is more than just Willy Wonka (here), evolving from the son of an assassinated duke into a force of nature... it would have been nice to embrace more of the unique trappings of the novels.
As much as Dune Two plays with religious archetypes and the universal appeal of “messiah” narratives, it adopts a decidedly skeptical posture toward the religious enterprise.

Dune: Part Two not only continues the brilliance of the first film but is a film that certainly sets a new bar for just how good sci-fi films should be. With stunning visuals, an engaging story and a cast at their very best this is a masterpiece.
Throughout Dune: Part Two, I caught myself looking at the time, not because I was bored and wanted to see how much time was left, but quite the opposite; I was dreading the film ending.
Dune: Part Two delivers mightily on the promises set in the first film with bountiful aplomb. It sets an incredibly high bar not only for blockbusters in 2024, but for sequels in this century.
Splitting the films now makes sense in terms of telling this story properly and patiently, and this feels like the payoff for our patience.
"D2" hits the ground howling and never lets up, lashed onward, once again, by the virtuoso camera strategies of Villeneuve and cinematographer Greig Fraser, and by Hans Zimmer's titanic score.
What began with an unfilmable novel is now one of the best double bills ever made.
To Villeneuve, size does matter.
The dazzling visuals and intimate moments help to compensate for the movie’s sometimes plodding pace.

A triumph of craft and storytelling that serves as a potent mirror to the first part, as hubristic political gamesmanship is supplanted by the tragic weaponisation of religion. It also has Javier Bardem surfing a sandworm into battle, so yeah, I loved it.
Dune: Part Two succeeds on its many storyline levels, big and small. Passion, power, corruption, oppression, romance, intimacy, and revenge all get their time in this sweeping spectacle.

Dune: Part Two doesn’t just feel like a rewarding conclusion to all the attempted screen adaptations of Herbert’s novels, but also the fullest expression of ideas, themes and aesthetics Villeneuve has been working towards throughout his career.

Dune: Part Two feels like the right film for this moment. In a post-Barbenheimer world, where big blockbusters can also have something to say, this is the perfect sandstorm of filmmaking, performances, and vision.
Neither a zippy adventure nor a metaphysical mind-bender, this Dune has the heaviness of an old-fashioned Hollywood epic.
This is the Imax experience the Avatar movies wish they could be: a spectacle with grand visuals and EQUALLY grand writing.

Regardless of whether there is more to come, this latest chapter emerges as one of the most well-crafted works of cinema you'll see this year. With both spectacle and soul, it is a work that puts all other projects of this scale to absolute shame.
The casual audience will like the incredible imagery of Villeneuve and the A-List cast supporting it.

"Dune: Part Two" tries to explore ideas about whether an outsider should lead and/or save a race of people, but the half-hearted efforts are almost as bad as if these notions hadn't been interrogated at all.
... While the script allows itself the space to deepen the theme and characters of the first film, the director expands the scale of his audiovisual film. [Full review in Spanish]
The best addition is Austin Butler as the baron’s bald-pated, hypervicious nephew. It’s official: Butler no longer looks or sounds like Elvis Presley.
It belongs firmly to Zendaya, who gives the second half of Denis Villeneuve’s Frank Herbert adaptation an emotional tangibility that the first, in all its exotic majesty, eschewed.

“Dune Part 2” is state-of-the-art commercial cinema as it exists in 2024: It takes you someplace far away and brings it up close, with broad archetypes, nods to Big Ideas, and every bit of its vision dotted down to the last pixel.
The serene beauty of the desert's quiet contrasts starkly with the intense conflict scenes in Dune: Part Two.
Familiar? You bet. Exciting? Absolutely. "Dune" is huge. The whole movie thrums with bombastic images and sound.

...with a larger cast, wider focus and comprehensible, sublime action set-pieces, this vindicates Villeneuve’s gamble to hold back key characters from the first film...a unique brand of inscrutable alien cultures and other-worldly cinematic spice...
Dune: Part Two brings the novel's themes to the forefront in a way that the first film could never quite manage, while also still delivering plenty of visceral action and awestruck world-building.

Dune: Part Two is undoubtedly one of this year’s biggest cinematic experiences as Denis Villeneuve and co. dive deeper into the desert. Outstanding on pretty much all levels, the sequel is visually thrilling and narratively epic.
The spice expands consciousness–I wish Denis Villeneuve had at least experimented with it before he decided to navigate the spaceways of this science fiction epic.
Dune Part 2, is a big, wild vision, an answer to the stately elegance of the first film. It’s blockbuster filmmaking writ large, exciting and laced with high stakes.
Dune: Part Two is a true cinematic experience. It needs to be seen on the big screen.
This is a cinematic, monumental film that is sure to blow audiences away with its pure spectacle.
'Dune Part Two' is another stunning sci-fi achievement from director Denis Villenueve.
Denis Villeneuve’s vision makes a powerful conclusion to Dune.

Saying that this film should be an hour longer sounds more loving that I intend, though my intentions are positive. As the conflict expands wider, the movie deserved to have the time and space that it allowed everything else in the film.
Yet more than five hours into this saga, and with no real end in sight, all that super-sized spectacle ends up like footprints in a sandstorm: barely leaving an impression beyond the end credits.
Big, bold, and equally grim as it is amorous, ‘Dune: Part Two’ inimitably balances its blockbuster psyche with an uncomfortable morality.
Your worm is waiting, jump on and hang on tight.
Villenueve's sense of scale is basically unmatched right now, and there are shots here that will take your breath away
... A science fiction masterpiece. [Full review in Spanish]

Dune: Part Two is bigger and bolder than the first installment, with sequences that range from beguiling and creative to brutal and commanding. Yet, he finds himself making some of the same mistakes that injured his 2021 feature.
Villeneuve aptly weaves the disparate threads of family, power, mysticism, religion, politics, and love in this second part of a strikingly visual film. Climb into the sandbox for this one.

Villeneuve’s film is a grand success, working on an even broader canvas than the first Dune -- but it’s tinged with deep mournfulness, a quality that sets it apart from its blockbuster contemporaries.

There is no shortage of sights and sounds to wow the senses in Dune: Part Two; the gigantic sandworms alone are worth the price of admission. But when the accompanying story becomes borderline incomprehensible, that visual feast winds up feeling hollow.
Now we know: Frank Herbert’s Dune can be filmed successfully... Villeneuve and his crew orchestrate this spectacle skilfully, without a trace of self-consciousness, let alone humour.

Villeneuve has taken the worst and most preachy bits from Avatar, about how imperialism is fuelled by the exploitation of natural resources, and seemingly repackaged them with an orange Instagram filter and a couple of dozen heavy brass “braaaaam”s...
It is precisely this discontinuous narration that makes "Dune: Part Two" a more uneven title than what lovers of fan-filled theaters could hope for. [Full review in Spanish]

Movies executed on this sprawling, daunting scale don’t come along every day. Furthermore, movies this large rarely deliver such a massively ambitious, yet finely detailed vision as what we encounter in Dune: Part Two.
“Dune: Part Two” builds a world that’s undeniably spectacular, compressing a sprawling, borderline incomprehensible story into an efficient narrative-delivery system.

Villeneuve, who has given science-fiction cinema a much-needed shot in the arm and has made the kind of Dune adaptation that makes everybody see what your cooler nerdy friends saw when they read the books back in high school.
A visionary imagining of Herbert’s book on screen... Like its predecessor, this is less a popcorn “Star Wars”-like space adventure than a quasi-art film disguised as popular entertainment.
Dune: Part Two is a stunning piece of cinema that brings the world of its source material to life, but can’t deliver a story that matches the brilliance of its world.
Starry sequel is mesmerizing from start to finish, but it's heavier than most sci-fi fare.
Cinematic escape velocity, instantly achieved. Next stop, Arrakis.
Dune 2 is the much-anticipated pay-off, a vast improvement over the mythology-laden first film. Epic battles scenes, palace intrigue, romance and religious prophecies abound.
Epic in scope and astonishing in its world-building, Dune: Part Two combines jaw-dropping visuals with imaginative action and morally complex plotting to thrilling effect
Outstanding...actually makes you feel like you’ve watched something with real dramatic substance – along with awesome, ginormous sandworms.
As a big-screen spectacle, Part Two exceeds Part One.
Even those who, like me, came into the theater more or less Dune-indifferent may find themselves wanting another chapter...

Aside from being such an exquisite technical achievement, what makes “Dune Part Two” a masterpiece is that it’s always interrogating that same story, and why we need to keep telling it to ourselves in our art, in our politics, in our religion.

Those of us who retain a stubborn fondness for Lynch’s much maligned adaptation will sense what’s missing from Villeneuve’s: an imaginative density, a hint of psychoerotic danger, the grotesque, teeming aliveness of a fully inhabited world.
An engrossing sci-fi spectacle.
Positively mind blowing --- director Denis Villeneuve and his magnificent cast and crew have created a nearly three-hour colossal achievement in filmmaking.
For sci-fi buffs, it doesn’t get any better than the highly imaginative and immensely entertaining DUNE: PART TWO.
…a true-blue(-eyed) triumph for modern mainstream cinema and an experience that can make even the biggest of projection screens feel even bigger.

In his follow-up to the masterful first chapter, director Denis Villeneuve barrels through a complex story line to offer a visual feast, serving up one of the most jaw dropping cinematic events in years.
Short of lassoing a sandworm, for the second film in a row, the screenwriting of Denis Villenueve and Jon Spaihts cannot achieve that next tier of swell and it painfully shows.

An absolute behemoth of filmmaking. A spectacular that truly serves the best cinema has to offer. It’s gigantic, epic, and sprawling... it engulfs your body and buries you in its immense scope and scale... This generation’s 'Return of the King.'
Director Denis Villeneuve’s latest is breathless in scope, action, and artistry.
If the first part was full of intrigue, politics and betrayal, the follow-up is its ponderous playing out
One way or another, if there is a movie so far this year that deserves to be seen on the biggest screen possible, it is this one. [Full review in Spanish]
Who says blockbusters can’t be high art?

Villeneuve’s production is a grand and convincing argument that films – at least of this sort- are required viewing in a theater setting, though even the vast IMAX screens upon which it will be shown will strain to contain this epic vision.
Dune: Part Two is a work of visceral beauty that proves that large-scale blockbusters can be exciting, mature, and deliver a captivating sci-fi epic. [Full review in Spanish]
“Dune: Part Two” is a sweeping and engaging continuation that will make you eager for a third installment.
Truly, it’s the best reason to get up off the couch at home and go see it for yourself, at the best movie theater you can afford. I don’t know what else to say.
A rushed and underdeveloped second chapter that feels strangely diminished compared to its predecessor.
A grand cinematic spectacle that takes its place as one of the greatest sci-fi films ever made
Technically it’s phenomenal. But also what it’s delivering is truly epic and made me appreciate and become more immersed in this world than the first film.
A masterful melding of massive spectacle, heartfelt high-stakes performances, and astonishing visual artistry, “Dune: Part Two” expands the mythic hero’s journey to its full potential.

Dune: Part Two is lightyears away from its predecessor, becoming a game changer for the science fiction genre. With powerful storytelling and a stronger cast, Dune: Part Two soars where most films dream of.
Denis Villeneuve delivers a massive, epic sci-fi spectacle with Dune Part Two, expanding the world and concepts first introduced in the books by Frank Herbert.
In all likelihood, Dune: Part Two will be revered in film history for years to come – it manages to be unlike anything we’ve seen before, yet comfortably familiar at the same time.
Denis Villeneuve successfully delivers on the setup established in Part 1, crafting an epic and gripping sci-fi tale that will captivate audiences.
Not since the Lord of the Rings movies has there been something this committed to its singular vision, this brash, and this handsome.

Villeneuve’s construction of Dune’s bizarre universe is done with such conviction that we go along with the story’s portentousness, just as we accept the spectacle of characters hurtling atop giant sandworms like so many chariot-driving Ben-Hurs.

A sandy sci-fi spectacle with overtones of a scarily familiar world, a spectacular, sprawling extravaganza that shows the remarkable effects, star-studded casting and thrilling big-screen wallop a budget north of $120 million can get you.
At its best when it uses the epic vistas of the desert to its advantage.
Cooking with bolder savory spice – unlike anyone else has ever done with Herbert’s words – Denis Villeneuve's Dune Part Two is a masterpiece.

Beyond tapping into the source material’s vast potential for emotion and sociopolitical commentary, [Villeneuve] applies a formal bravado and seriousness found in history’s most substantial works of science fiction.
A rousing, heartfelt and breathtaking spectacle.
Denis Villeneuve once again proves that he has desert power.
Director Denis Villeneuve comes up with a cracker of a starry action-laden sequel.
Villeneuve has gone beyond his influences to create a hefty piece of sci-fi world-building that is lost in the spate of films that need to have delineated heroes and villains.
Denis Villeneuve’s sequel captures the bleakness and the tragedy at the heart of Frank Herbert’s novel.
Folks, it's like this: if you liked or loved Dune: Part One, you will like or love Dune: Part Two.
There is an emotional depth to it that's missing in the worldbuilding of the initial installment.
Villeneuve’s bold stylistic choices, along with the penetrating score by Hans Zimmer result in a film that intensely washes over the senses as it pummels the viewer with beauty and brutality.

Granted, a number of character arcs and subplots are resolved perfunctorily, and a handful of defining moments get zero time to breathe. The rest of it, though? The rest of it is impressively close to perfect.
Denis Villeneuve magnifies the myth of his creation with a pluperfect staging, both epic and poetic, of Frank Herbert's text. [Full review in Spanish]
It rivals 2015’s “Mad Max: Fury Road” as a staggering, monumental achievement in genre filmmaking and reminds us what truly talented movie directors can do.

Yes, it is a gorgeous production but not a masterpiece. I’ll be brave and say it: Walken is a feeble lopsided emperor, Bardem is over-acting in his own movie and Bautista’s emotional decimal is higher than everyone else. Only Butler ignites the movie.
Dune: Part Two is a momentous, jaw-dropping and masterful achievement in cinema that stakes its claim to be the best film of 2024.
A feast for the eyes...Dune: Part Two's jaw-dropping epicness is enough to satisfy one's appetite for spice, cementing itself as one of the best sci-fi sequels of this century.

Sci-Fi fans rejoice, DUNE PART 2 is truly remarkable! Denis Villeneuve achieves perfection in this immersive cinematic experience, which includes Zimmer's masterful score and Fraser's best work yet. This is a genuine sci-fi masterpiece!
While the war may be portrayed as a jaw-dropping spectacle, the answers to all those political and moral questions may leave the audience deeply uncomfortable. Herbert would be proud.
The film has the makings of a contemporary classic, with the only downside being that we’ll have to wait another few years to see how tensions unfold.

Dune: Part Two isn’t just an embarrassment of narrative and retinal riches; it’s the sort of big-canvas franchise storytelling we haven’t see since The Lord of the Rings came to a close back at the shire.
In a film that could have rested on being a visual masterpiece, Villeneuve stays true to the humanity of his direction.
Dune: Part Two surpasses even the highest expectations, establishing itself as an unquestionable technical masterpiece of blockbuster filmmaking.
While not quite as groundbreaking as the debut film, Denis Villeneuve pays faithful respect to the source material by putting a complex story ahead of action-oriented spectacle.

The sequel is slower paced than the first installment with the director taking time for Paul Atreides (Timothée Chalamet) to prove himself the messiah to the Freman, which left little time for Paul’s transition.

Villenueve has put forth considerable effort to mitigate potential issues with the novel's 'white savior' material, but in the end, has made a movie that is entirely too rad and 'dudes rock' for those efforts to matter or be particularly effective.
A stunning below the line masterpiece that takes surprising and even dark tones, with brilliant performances by Chalamet and Ferguson, even if the story goes by very fast at the core of the film.
Villeneuve’s second chapter tops it’s fantastic predecessor in every possible way with exquisite set pieces, gorgeous visual design, astounding action, and a stunning cast.
Manages to keep the storytelling relatively straight and find a human element within all the dense mythology- plus, it's consistently exciting.

The sequel, while impressive, loses the restraint and elegance of the first film, leaning more towards a blockbuster experience. The quiet confidence of Part One has morphed into unshackled bravura in Part Two.

Dune Part Two is Empire Strikes Back level great. You have a lead character put to the test and rising to the occasion in epic fashion. The scale is dynamic, and Butler's portrayal is wildly hypnotic and menacing. This is greatness on every level.

Watching Dune 2, was like watching The Dark Knight for the first time. Similar to the eternally praised Batman film, Dune 2 feels so good and fulfilling that it will stand out: no matter what came before or comes after it. #diandrareviews

Villeneuve's epic is an incredibly immersive and narratively rich awe-inspiring sci-fi feast. It's so strong across the board that not even an overlong second act and a rushed resolution can diminish its impact. [Full review in Spanish]
Dune: Part Two is an epic continuation and builds the potential of what could be one of the greatest science fiction trilogies of all time.
With an impeccable cast and even grander ambition on display, Dune: Part Two soars as a feat of storytelling. It’s destined to join the ranks of the great sequels and visually stuns at every turn.

Blockbuster and IP filmmaking at its finest. Dune: Part Two rocks a script that doesn’t shy away from character complexities, and does a shockingly solid job of reacquainting viewers with the Dune chessboard while adding more pieces to it.

Despite the long runtime and sluggish first half, "Dune: Part Two" finds its footing in sweeping landscapes aided by gorgeous cinematography, sound design that's loud as all get out, and a host of standout performances from its A-list cast.
Dune: Part Two is better and spicier than the first, packed with star power, and still too long. Commentary on religion and fanaticism send mixed messages.

Heavy with spectacle and theme as it is, Part Two is often surprisingly nimble. As a filmmaker, Villeneuve has long had trouble balancing plot with picture, but here he almost gets the calibration exactly right.
“Dune: Part Two” not only does justice to Herbert’s groundbreaking novel, it eclipses 2021’s “Dune” both in scale and ambition.

Villeneuve’s great talent lies, I think, in invocation. He may be less perfect when it comes to conclusions but he’s brilliant at summoning -- a sense of doom, a suddenly appeared spacecraft, a sandworm.

Emotion and hero's journey complexity course through Denis Villeneuve’s Dune: Part Two like spice, ensuring viewers stay alert and riveted by the sweeping story in addition to basking in astonishing audio/visual spectacle
Dune: Part Two is a truly stunning visual spectacle with a hero’s journey at its heart and is a film that you want to see on the biggest screen possible.

Dune: Part Two is a masterful technical achievement that surpasses its predecessor movie on a storytelling level. It’s less cluttered with characters than 2021’s Dune and has a more compelling villain and higher emotional stakes.

A triumphant middle chapter that grapples with inner darkness, ruminative notions of prophecy and destiny, romantic entanglement, and familial tragedy in what is set to be one of the great trilogies and a true modern masterwork.
If you're casting a hero whose Chosen One origin is 'I'm The Chosen One: I Have A Note From My Mommy.' Timothée Night Shyamalan is the actor you want.
Dune Part Two is a thrilling edge of your seat epic with high stakes, breathtaking filmmaking, and lasting visuals that are all enhanced by another Hans Zimmer score that deepens its emotional core.
Denis Villeneuve's sci-fi sequel suffers from some of the same issues as its predecessor, but 'Dune Part Two' such a well-made and well-acted mega-movie that it barely matters
A spectacular feat of science-fiction filmmaking, marrying immersive world-building with engrossing storytelling.

As blockbuster movies go, Dune: Part Two is a thrilling ride that totally earns its two-and-a-half-hour running time. The filmmakers add much-needed heft to their display of virtuoso filmmaking by adding serious real-life themes.

Denis Villeneuve's Dune: Part Two shatters already sky-high expectations by immersing the viewer in a deeply layered, complex narrative. The film takes a Game of Thrones approach to the brutality, politics, and spiritual machinations of fiery revenge.
It's even more epic than the last. Sound design, costume, and cinematography were firing on all cylinders. This movie is the definition of why people go to the movies. A must see.
He has created an exceptional film and a franchise that has set a new standard for sci-fi.
Dune: Part Two is a The Empire Strikes Back or The Return of the King-level event. A science fiction classic in the making that’ll inspire the next generation of science fiction and fantasy films.
It’s difficult not to get wrapped up in the visuals; the way in which the Dune novel’s many signature characters and adventures are realized are simply stunning.
An absorbing viewing experience and wholly immersive descent into sci-fi storytelling, frequently sold with incredible magnitude.
...gets in your nostrils...
The only major issue I can even find with Dune: Part Two is that we had to sit through all of Dune: Part One just to get to the movie Denis Villeneuve actually wanted to make.
I know that people use this as a meme, but, whatever. This is cinema. This is why big screen cinematic experiences exist.

Dune Part Two is almost 3 hours long, and it still left me wanting more. Denis Villeneuve is back with another sweeping epic. It has to be seen on the biggest screen and the loudest speakers, and the Dolby Atmos version I experienced was shaking my seats.
‘Dune: Part Two’ turns up the cinematic heat with a darker, more involving chapter. [It's] the epitome of cerebral entertainment.
Though visually a knock-out, Denis Villeneuve's second installment repeatedly sheds momentum, something no 166-minute epic can afford to lose.

Here, there’s something even more insidious at play that Villeneuve scratches at. It sees a future where a strand of religious fanaticism embodied within a single person can turn a culture inside out from within.

Villeneuve amps up the operatic elements in this dense, beautiful, brash second chapter. The messy messianic message is filtered through modern eyes to its benefit, and in the end this game of thrones is as bloody and brilliant as hoped for
The film is a feverish dream of another world that feels as real and elusive as sand slipping through your fingertips... It's a place one would never want to be, and yet you do not want to leave.

Part Two surpasses the first in almost every way. It is a technical masterpiece, as expected, but even the writing is a step up. It left me with this beautiful feeling that I had just experienced something truly special.
What Villeneuve and company achieve in Dune: Part Two is every bit as impressive and, in its peak imagery, hypnotic as part one.
Dune: Part Two is an awe-inspiring, visually stunning sci-fi spectacle and a devastating collision of myth and destiny on a galactic scale
In an era when old sci-fi war horses Star Trek and Star Wars have stalled their big screen outings, and, at a time when sequels and reboots galore die at the box office, thank God for Dune Part Two.
Visually, at least, Dune: Part Two is a masterpiece... the film is regularly wondrous while also presenting a very gritty and lived-in world.
The movie fairly throbs with conflicts and intrigues, all the more so if you see it on an IMAX screen with the deep bass of Hans Zimmer’s majestic score rumbling through your body.
It may take five and a half hours for his character to truly come to life, but two films in, Chalamet’s evolution as Paul gives everything a center.
It shouldn’t work, honestly. There’s too much going on in too many directions at the same time. But Villeneuve brings it all together somehow.
A true epic, this film is visually stunning, intense and suspenseful, and boasts a phenomenal cast who all bring their A-game. Timothée Chalamet is on another level.
Dune: Part Two is a screen-quaking cinematic landmark that should hold the future of blockbuster filmmaking accountable.
Dune: Part Two ups the ante in every way compared to the first film, and both movies combined form an incredible story of power and tribulation.
The last act doesn't quite land, but the opening two hours make for some of Villeneuve's finest work.
In terms of pure spectacle and shock-and-awe achievement, Villeneuve has produced an adaptation of mad glory and power.
One of the best blockbusters of the century so far, and an instant sci-fi classic.
…In an era where heroism and saviors are taken at face value, Dune: Part Two redefines what kind of stories blockbusters can tell.
A deeper and richer sequel aimed at grown-up sci-fi fans.
The technology here is magic: something to be felt in your soul, not puzzled out in your head.
Our blockbuster drought is over, thanks to a brilliant sequel set on a sweltering desert planet.
Part Two rights the cosmic battleship with plenty of staggering visuals, all the gigantic sandworms you’d ever want, plus a deeper thematic exploration of power, colonialism and religion.
Featuring absolutely staggering visuals, Dune: Part Two is an arresting, transportive middle entry in Denis Villeneuve’s tricky sci-fi saga.
The art of cinematic spectacle is alive and rocking in “Dune: Part Two,” and it’s a blast.

Dune: Part Two has a few issues, most of which can be linked back to the decision to make this a true Part One and Part Two experience, but they aren't pervasive enough to ruin an overall excellent film.
An instant landmark of its genre.

The first film tackled the hard work of arranging the game pieces on the board, so Part Two swiftly sets about bashing them into one another. All those factional conflicts roiling away throughout the first film finally get to boil over at last.

After somewhat laboriously placing those chess pieces on the board in the first Dune, Villenueve and co-screenwriter Jon Spaihts send them into strategic alliances and conflicts, and the results are often breathtaking.
This is a real epic and it is exhilarating to find a film-maker thinking as big as this.
Dune: Part 2 is an epic experience on the big screen.
A masterful sequel that improves on the already excellent original.

Extraordinary filmmaking. While the first film was impressive, this sequel is one of the greatest sci-fi / war films of all time. Visually stunning but this time also strong character development & commentary. Also lots of inventive action. A must see.

You might expect a big-budget space opera to exhilarate you and move you, and on those terms Villeneuve's sprawling, pretentious folly has to count as an abject failure. But if you want to feel awestruck, that's another matter.

Blockbuster filmmaking at its finest... There’s so much accomplished here that stems from the confidence of the filmmakers involved and their trust in the audience’s willingness to dive even deeper into the world of Arrakis.

Part Two possesses state-of-the-art cinematic qualities that reward soaking in its grandeur... After the initial promise, though, the film only sporadically rises to the level of its sky-high expectations.
Villeneuve has outdone himself. More importantly, he’s done justice to the scope and scale and sheer weirdness of a stoner-lit touchstone’s back half without, pun intended, sanding away its edges.
It takes a good stretch of precious screentime for Part Two to play as anything other than a thoroughgoing, checklist-meeting obligation bolstered by obvious craft.
Director Denis Villeneuve’s adaptation of Frank Herbert’s sprawling sci-fi classic is true to its source material in terms of scope (it’s huge!) and complexity (its plotting is very dense).
Things get spicier in Dune: Part Two with a messier entry. Embracing the weirdness of the source material has done wonders for the tone.

...a sumptuous world of political machinations, messianic legend, and the nefarious grit of war-making. DUNE: Part Two is not only gorgeous filmmaking and storycraft, but its boots are on the necks of who humanity is now.
Another epic helping of sci-fi wildness from Denis Villeneuve that’ll take true believers to paradise — even if it’s a bit too much Spice to digest in one sitting.

If you like the aesthetic of Dune so far, and you like cinematic spectacle, the movie should scratch that itch on a basic level. But when it comes to fully delivering on the promise of the first, well, once again we are left hanging.
Dune: Part Two belongs in the ranks of film's best sequels and sci-fi offerings.
Immersive, impressive, and wildly exhilarating, it’s an adrenaline rush to the head and heart, soaring in its breathtaking action sequences as much as it sings in its refined, evocative stillness.
This is sharper, slicker, more resonant than the first installment.
Drops viewers right back into the world of Dune. It is a seamless follow-up to 2021's first part, with some new additions to the tale.
There are moments in Dune: Part Two that feel so audacious, they play out as if they were already etched onto the cinematic canon.
"Dune: Part Two" is a rare big, expensive blockbuster with a lot on its mind.
Denis Villeneuve [delivers] another cinematic tour de force in Dune: Part Two; a hugely ambitious, contemplative sci-fi epic... which may also be the bleakest blockbuster ever made.

A sci-fi epic for the ages: a sweeping tragedy of mythic proportions, a cautionary tale of the perils of zealotry. It’s a towering feat of sci-fi cinema that will put Dune: Part Two in contention for the pantheon of greatest sequels ever.

Could Herbert’s trippy Dune Messiah be adapted next, as teased? Tall order, that. But on the strength of this extravagantly, rigorously realized vision, make no mistake: Villeneuve is the man to see a way through that delirious desert storm.
Plagued by a nagging shallowness when it comes to portraying the Fremen... the film has difficulty fully embracing the nuance of Herbert’s anti-imperial and ecologically dystopian text.
Whatever you do, don’t mistake this follow-up for a sequel. It’s the second half of a saga...
Villeneuve’s bold, brash presentation can sometimes feel bereft of personality, but it’s not short on vision, which it has in spades.

A masterpiece of breath-taking landscapes, incredible special effects and awe-inspiring action. Dune: Part Two is a complex and gorgeously layered production that could well be Villeneuve's best work to date.

Part Two would be an epic achievement from any other director, but it feels that there is something bigger, better and obviously more decisive to come in the third and hopefully final part of the trilogy.
Glorious! A cinematic masterpiece in all of its splendor. Villeneuve has outdone himself. Even better than Part One. The production and filmmaking are god tier. [Full review in Spanish]

Dune: Part Two is more than a mere sequel. It’s a continuation, culmination, and ultimately a fantastic elevation of everything you already loved about director Denis Villeneuve’s 2021 film Dune: Part One.
Dune: Part Two is as huge an improvement upon its predecessor as The Dark Knight was to Batman Begins.

Not only does this new movie pick up exactly where the last one left off, it also carries over the strengths and weaknesses that made the previous chapter so astonishing to look at but stultifying to watch.

The story may never break free of its more dated tropes, but the Dune movies represent a remarkable collection of talent coming together to, if nothing else, remind us of the power of epic storytelling on a big screen.
“Dune: Part Two” is a robust piece of filmmaking, a reminder that this kind of broad-scale blockbuster can be done with artistry and flair.
I could watch Timothée Chalamet and Zendaya stare into each other’s deep blue eyes all day.
2024's first Best Picture contender
Part Two picks up where the first instalment left off, literally and figuratively, delivering another stunning set of gorgeous visuals and exceptional action sequences.

Dune Part 2 left me speechless. A powerhouse epic masterpiece that becomes the TWO TOWERS of this decade. A special type of movie that only comes around every so often & will make you believe in what the magic of filmmaking can create.

DUNE: PART TWO is nothing short of MONUMENTAL and one of the BEST sequels of all time. Denis Villeneuve accomplishes the impossible in crafting a massive and intricate film you need to see to believe.
Dune: Part Two is a visually-monumental blockbuster that excels in cinematic spectacle.
[Boasting] an ambitious and exhilarating story that matches its style, it’s the finest thing Villeneuve has helmed and the 2024 film to beat for outsized sci-fi showmanship.
Stands in stark contrast to so many other shallow blockbusters of recent years.
Movies are always enjoyed best on the biggest screen, but never has a movie demanded an IMAX screen more than Dune: Part Two. Get yourself to the biggest screen you can to enjoy this.

Dune: Part Two is as visually stunning and epic as the first movie, wrapping up this near-perfect two-part adaptation of Frank Herbert's book with an even more impressive cast in an action-packed epic.
Dune: Part Two delivers on the promise of the prior installment and showcases epic science fiction on the grandest of scales.
Dune: Part Two builds upon what the first film established, expanding and improving this deeply rich and complex universe in nearly every aspect.
Dune: Part 2 is the year's first great film, and you won't see a bigger or better blockbuster all year... a sophisticated sci-fi masterpiece, an instant classic, and an unprecedented sequel.

A stirring piece of grown-up sci-fi delivering more spectacle than you’d see in several ordinary blockbusters stitched together. If it only wins our minds, not our hearts, it’s still one hell of a battle.

Reminiscent of the way Zack Snyder always goes maximum-effort operatic, but with a sense of discerning taste, Denis Villeneuve’s film is ultimately awe-inspiring and an immersive cinematic spectacle that is often breathtaking.
Denis Villeneuve’s film, like its predecessor, offers an object lesson in the visual splendor made possible by meticulously storyboarded minimalist maximalism.

An incredibly innovative film, with jaw-dropping visuals, powerful performances, an impeccable score, and complex themes, Dune Part II is the closest a blockbuster has been to perfection since The Lord of the Rings.
A spicy sequel that is ultimately a full sensory experience, one of the rare film sequels that is better than the predecessor.

Villeneuve has fully realized his dream of adapting Frank Herbert's beloved novel with the profoundness, respect, and scale it deserves in a tour de force of filmmaking we rarely see anymore. This is why we go to the movies.
A bonafide masterpiece that delivers on the promise of the first movie, while adding so much more in terms of layers and depth.

Dune: Part Two is Denis Villeneuve’s Empire Strikes Back & Lawrence of Arabia. It is a sci-fi opera that is grand in scale with a hypnotizing and emotionally devastating story. Villeneuve’s immersive cinematic nirvana is a sci-fi masterpiece.

Dune: Part Two leaves a promising franchise with more questions than answers as to whether this is the type of blockbuster we want made going forward: rocky attention to detail with the feeling of being rushed matched with an exhausted runtime.
“Dune: Part 2” is the perfect filmmaking tapestry where every fiber is meticulously woven to create the perfect film. It’s an epic masterful cinematic experience.

synopsis: "Dune: Part Two" will explore the mythic journey of Paul Atreides as he unites with Chani and the Fremen while on a warpath of revenge against the conspirators who destroyed his family. Facing a choice between the love of his life and the fate of the known universe, he endeavors to prevent a terrible future only he can foresee.
